speaker: Teacher
text: So we continue from where we left off with a new student. Hello, Sonya.

speaker: Teacher
text: And I wanted to take this opportunity just to remind, uh, the learners at home how to use these audios to make sure that you are not just listening and following and understanding what's going on, but always taking the time and pausing, if necessary, to think through the sentence and say the answer out loud before we hear the response of the student here. That's really important for us to take French away from this experience. The pauses are always around a second and a half, that's because the track's been edited. Maybe the student here answers after one second, maybe after a minute, but that's always going to be edited so feel free to pause and take whatever time you need to have the thoughts that you need to have to confidently and correctly build the sentence. This course has been very carefully thought out to guide certain thoughts, and these thoughts are the most important thing about what we're doing. So you shouldn't be worrying about memorizing or how much of this will I remember, or writing things down. You should only care about following the explanations, having the thoughts that you have when you follow those explanations, and then building the sentence in your own time. What was "I want" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good, but the "veux" here is sounding like a B, and this is of course because you're a Spanish speaker. So you will have to make a special effort to make sure that you get the "veux" [fricative V sound] sound here, rather than a harder "buh."

speaker: Teacher
text: Much better. Very good. "Je veux." [fricative V sound] And "I can"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je peux." Good. And we said that both of these are spelled "E-U-X," no? "V-E-U-X" or "P-E-U-X." And that "X" is silent, no? "Je veux," [fricative V sound] "je peux." What was the word for "late," like, uh, "tardy"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. But what happened to that last "D"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Yes, it's silent, right? Just like the "X" on the end of "je veux," [fricative V sound] "je peux." So give that another go.

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. So as we were seeing, we have to pay attention though to the fact that mostly we won't pronounce consonants written on the end of words in French. "I must." Or "I have to" is "je dois." "Je dois."

speaker: Teacher
text: Related to the word "debt" in English. That's where that "D" comes from. "Je dois." And this is spelled "D-O-I-S." "Dois." So we end in an "S" but we don't hear it. "Je dois." The word for "thing" was "chose." How was "something"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Quelque chose." "Something." How would we say "reparation," "reparation" in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Réparation." [uvular R sound] So the "R" in French we will hear sounding differently in different accents or dialects of French. It can sound more like a "ruh" [uvular R sound] sound or it can sound more like a "ruh" [uvular R sound] sound, like a gargling sound, which might be hard for an English speaker, for example, to incorporate, not to associate a "ruh" [uvular R sound] with an "R" which a "ruh" [uvular R sound] sounds maybe like a "G" or a "G-H" or something like that, no? But you can pronounce it like an R. It is pronounced like an R in various dialects of French. "Réparation." [uvular R sound] "Réparation." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "I have to repair something." [uvular R sound] "I must," "I have to repair something." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je dois réparer quelque chose." [uvular R sound] What was the word for "late" again?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tard." Good. And "later" or "more late"? How was that?

speaker: Teacher
text: Almost. We don't have the "S" though.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Plus tard." So again, we don't pronounce that final consonant, no. We have "plus" written, like "plus" in English, but we pronounce "plu." "Plus tard." "I have to repair something later." [uvular R sound] "I have to," "I must repair something later." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Student - Sonya
text: Je dois réparer quelque chose plus tard.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je dois réparer quelque chose plus tard." [uvular R sound] So I mentioned how "dois" is related to the word "debt" in English, and in fact, "je dois" other than "I must," "I have to," also means "I owe." So actually when you say "I have to," "I must," "je dois," you are saying "I owe," "I owe to whatever." "You must" or "you owe" is "tu dois." "Tu dois."

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. So this "u" sound is like in "plus," "plus tard." And we point our lips out for this. "U," "tu."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu." The word for "30," "30," is "trente," [nasal 'a' sound] "trente." [nasal 'a' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Yes. So you could say, for example, "you owe 30 euros." [uvular R sound] "You owe 30 euros." [uvular R sound] So give me the first bit first. "You owe 30."

speaker: Student - Sonya
text: Tu dois, no. Tu dois trente.

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. And now "euros." [uvular R sound] Now, knowing what we know about French so far, how might you pronounce "euros"? [uvular R sound] Thinking of how that's written, how might that sound in French?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. You didn't pronounce the last "S." You left that off. And also here we have "EU," like in "veux," [fricative V sound] like in "peux." So, we can also look back there. Go, "Okay, I know what an EU does in French," and we can import that sound over.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Euros," [uvular R sound] very good. So we have the "EU" like [French 'eu' sound]. We have the "R," which can sound like an "R" or it can sound more like "oe" [uvular R sound]. Also, if you know it, like the "gamma" in Greek, a little bit like this, "euro," [uvular R sound] because we don't pronounce the last "S" either. Very good. So, give me that. "You owe 30 euros." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu dois trente [nasal 'a' sound] euros." [uvular R sound] Very good. So, "dois," although literally meaning "owe," we will use much more like "have to," "must." What was "the door" in French? Like "Porteau"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "La porte." [uvular R sound] Very good. "You must repair the door." [uvular R sound] "You have to repair the door." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois réparer la porte." [uvular R sound] Very good. So with "door," "Porte," no? We end with a consonant sound, no? We end with a "Tə," with a "T" sound. But we said we don't usually pronounce consonants on the end of words. But this "T" is not on the end of "Porte." "Porte" is spelled "P-O-R-T-E." The same with "trente," [nasal 'a' sound] "30," which is spelt "T-R-E-N-T-E." So, the final "E" means the consonant isn't on the end of the word anymore. And so we know that we should pronounce it "Porte." So we said "tu dois réparer la porte." [uvular R sound] And we might want to get in the habit of noticing in French when we have a part of a word that's a building block, like the "re" [clear open E sound] here, "reparé." [clear open E sound] "R-E" is a building block, like in "commander," [nasal 'a' sound] "to recommander." [nasal 'a' sound] When you notice these common building blocks and experiment with moving and switching them, you will more easily be able to jump between words, different words in French. Going from, for example, "repair," "reparé," [clear open E sound] to "compare," which might be what in French? "To compare."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Comparer." [nasal 'o' sound] Good. So, we found that. We found "comparer" [nasal 'o' sound] without even having an "-ation" word, no? We don't have "compar-ation" in English. It's "comparison." But we found "comparer" [nasal 'o' sound] by identifying "re" [clear open E sound] as something that we stuck onto "paré" to get "reparé." [clear open E sound] And that allows us to move between words, like "comparé," [nasal 'o' sound] "réparé," [clear open E sound] "préparé." [clear open E sound] "You must compare." [nasal 'o' sound] How would you say that? "You must compare"? [nasal 'o' sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu dois comparer." [nasal 'o' sound] "The car." "The car" in French is "la voiture." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Voiture." [uvular R sound] So this is spelled "V-O-I." The "O-I" there gives us "wa" [French 'wa' sound], like in "doit," which is spelled "D-O-I-S." So, the "O-I" again there giving us "wa" [French 'wa' sound], "vois." "T-U," like the word for "U," "tur." [uvular R sound] "R-E." And we end in that R [uvular R sound] sound. "La," it's feminine, "the car." "La voiture." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "The car." "I have to repair the car." [uvular R sound] "I have to repair the car." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je dois réparer la voiture." [uvular R sound] "Can you prepare the car"? [uvular R sound] "Can you prepare the car"? [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Peux-tu," or just "tu peux préparer la voiture"? [uvular R sound] "Can you repair the car a little later"? [uvular R sound] "Can you repair the car a little later"? [uvular R sound] Let's think about one bit at a time. "Can you"?

speaker: Student - Sonya
text: Peux-tu réparer la voiture un peu plus tard?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu peux" or "peux-tu réparer la voiture un peu plus tard"? [uvular R sound, nasal 'un' sound] Very good. What was "to reserve"? [uvular R sound] If you don't just remember what "to reserve" was, of course you can look back to "reservation."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Réserver." [uvular R sound] Very good. "You must reserve the car." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois réserver la voiture." [uvular R sound]

speaker: Teacher
text: "Machine" is the same word in French, "machine." And it's written the same as in English, "M-A-C-H-I-N-E." How might it be pronounced in French? "Machine"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Machine" [laughs]. The same more or less, no? So we end in "N-E." So we pronounce that last consonant. We pronounce that "N" on the end because it's "N-E." The "N" isn't actually on the end. "Machine." And like in "chose," "the word for thing," we have "C-H" giving us "sh." And it's a feminine word, so how would you say "the machine"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "La machine." "You must reserve the machine." "You must reserve the machine."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu dois réserver la machine." And like in some other Latin languages, like Italian, for example, and also some dialects of Spanish. I don't know if you've heard this, "la maquina," for "the car." But "la machine," eh, may, you may still hear it used in some dialects of French to also mean "the car." "La machine."
